newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian shares down on profit taking.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian shares down on profit taking.

text.p: Slovenian shares eased on Tuesday as short-term profit taking took the steam out of a recent rally and market participants the decline could continue short term.
The 10-share SBI index fell 3.91 points to 1,188.9, the first fall after five days of gains.
"Many short-term investors are realising their profits by selling shares that rose recently," said Karmen Cerar, a trader at brokerage Poteza.
Turnover rose to 172.1 million tolars from 106.4 million. Overall 10 shares fell, four rose, three remained unchanged and eight were untraded.

Drug maker Lek A issue was again the most actively traded, falling 0.05 percent to 20,000 tolars on volume of 4,829 shares. Lek has dominated trading since September when it listed its "A" issue, attracting foreign buyers to the bourse.
Preferred shares of Dolenjska bank were the leading decliner, falling 8.70 percent to 10,500 tolars on volume of 11 shares.

Brokerage Dadas was the biggest gainer, rising 5.69 percent to 9,850 tolars on volume of 60 shares. Traders said Dadas rose in a technical reaction to Monday's sharp fall. -- Ljubljana newsroom, 386-61-125-8439
